citations.desc: Records: Operators of auction sales and brokers.
citations.narrative:
The facility did not have complete acquisition records for numerous animals consigned to the auction during the March
2023 and May 2024 auctions. The records for one Red kangaroo, three Patagonian Cavies, one African Crested
porcupine, one serval, three Mountain coatimundis, and one lemur were incomplete, missing the vehicle license number
and state for unlicensed consignors of these animals.
Fully completed acquisition and disposition records for all animals consigned at an auction are necessary to accurately
track and identify animals being used in regulated activities, as well as aid in the detection of movement of animals upon
relocation to a new site.
The auction must document the USDA license number, if the individual is licensed, or vehicle license number and state
and the driver's license number and state, if he or she is not licensed, for consigners and buyers at the sale.
Correct by August 5, 2024.

citations.desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
citations.narrative:
At the time of the inspection, the facility representative was unable to locate the required program of veterinary care and
contingency plan for review. Review of essential records at a facility ensures they are operating as intended to safeguard
the welfare of the animals housed and auctioned by the facility. The facility shall ensure that records required by the
Animal Welfare Act (AWA) and animal welfare regulations are available for APHIS officials to review on all inspections.
Correct by August 2, 2024.

citations.desc: Procurement of dogs, cats, and other animals; dealers.
citations.narrative:
Upon review of the March 2023 and May 2024 exotic auction records, the following animals were accepted and sold by
the auction from individuals without a valid USDA license: one kangaroo (tag E23); three Patagonian Cavies (tag E33,
E35, E36), one porcupine (tag E34); one serval (tag E81), three coatimundis (tag E82, E83, E84), and one lemur (tag
E85). When asked which species of lemur was consigned, the licensee stated they were unsure, only documenting the
type of animal received.
Individuals maintaining a valid USDA license when acquiring and/or dispositioning wild and exotic animals ensures
appropriate welfare oversight is maintained and continually reviewed for the animals housed, cared for, and transported
by the respective facilities. No dealer or exhibitor shall knowingly obtain any dog, cat, or other animal from any person
who is required to be licensed but who does not hold a current, valid, and unsuspended license.
Correct by July 26, 2024.

At least two areas adjacent to the stalls used to house animals during recent auctions remain overly cluttered, in addition
to one additional area alongside the front perimeter fence line. Excess amounts of accumulated boxes, enclosures in
disrepair, buckets, baskets, and other miscellaneous items remain stored in these areas. The extent of the storage
involved stacks of the aforementioned items, preventing the facility from effecting cleaning and maintaining husbandry
practices on the grounds. No one at the facility could visually assess or verify the condition of these areas where the items
were held.
Excess accumulation and collection of unused items can attract pests harboring diseases that can be spread to regulated
animals, as well as make it difficult to maintain husbandry standards and assess the integrity of the surrounding
infrastructure and grounds in these areas.
The premise grounds shall be kept clean and in good repair in order to prevent animals from injury and facilitate good
husbandry practices that place accumulations of trash in designated areas and cleared as necessary to protect the health
of the animals.
Correct by August 14, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee and facility representative.
